documentType: FBI 302 (Interview Report) and Laboratory Examination Records
summary: This document set contains FBI interview reports (FD-302s) with Bureau of Prisons correctional officers regarding the discovery of Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, and subsequent FBI Laboratory records concerning a request for handwriting analysis on a letter possibly written by Epstein. The interviews detail the immediate response to the incident and the officers' roles, while the lab records show the FBI was unable to conclusively analyze handwriting due to a lack of verified known samples. This is an FBI Laboratory case note detailing a questioned documents examination related to Lab #2020-01577-1. The examination analyzes various documents submitted as purported known writing of Jeffrey Epstein and items addressed to Larry Nassar, assessing their suitability for handwriting comparison and analyzing indented writing. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in July 2019, including his housing status, commissary list, an incident report of an attempted hanging, and related disciplinary forms. It also includes an FBI Laboratory case report and communication log regarding the examination of documents possibly linked to Epstein. This document consists of two parts: a series of screenshots from a furniture website (Artefacto) dated September 8, 2014, and an email exchange from August 11, 2020, between an FBI Special Agent and a Document Analyst regarding the submission and processing of evidence under case NY-3151227/Lab #2020-01577. The email discusses the shipment of evidence to the FBI Laboratory's Questioned Documents Unit. This document is an FBI Laboratory report and related email correspondence regarding a handwriting analysis request (Lab #2020-01577). The FBI's Questioned Documents Unit was asked to determine if a letter addressed to Larry Nassar, found as 'return to sender' from Jeffrey Epstein's cell, was written by Epstein. The examiner concluded meaningful comparisons could not be made due to a lack of verified, comparable known handwriting samples from Epstein. This document is a compilation of FBI records related to the death investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes an interview with a Bureau of Prisons camera technician about the malfunctioning video system at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) on the day of Epstein's death, an investigation into a threat against former MCC guard Tova Noel, and logs related to the collection and examination of digital evidence (DVR hard drives) from the MCC. This document contains an FBI Digital Forensics Analysis Unit (DFAU) report detailing the forensic examination of a Digital Video Recorder (DVR) system, likely from a property associated with Jeffrey Epstein. The report describes attempts to recover video data, hardware failures, and the creation of forensic copies. It is followed by email correspondence regarding evidence custody with the OCME (Office of the Chief Medical Examiner) and a deferred prosecution agreement for two individuals. This document contains two deferred prosecution agreements filed in the same criminal case (1:19-cr-00830-AT). The agreements are for defendants Michael Thomas and Tova Noel, both Bureau of Prisons employees accused of falsifying count and round slips at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 9-10, 2019. The agreements outline conditions for deferring prosecution, including cooperation with investigations and community service. This document is a compilation of FBI records related to the death investigation of Jeffrey Epstein, focusing on evidence handling. It includes a judge's approval of a deferred prosecution agreement for correctional officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas, multiple FBI Electronic Communications detailing the release and return of evidence to the Office of the Inspector General (OIG), extensive evidence chain of custody forms (FD-1004), property receipts (FD-597), and internal emails. The records document the transfer of digital evidence (hard drives, DVRs) and physical evidence from the FBI to OIG, the subsequent return of some items, and the eventual closure of the investigation after determining the death was a suicide.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The FBI is attempting to verify if a letter addressed to Larry Nassar, found as 'return to sender' from Epstein's cell, was written by him. He is listed as the victim in a death investigation.

persons.name: Reyes
persons.context: An inmate who was previously Epstein's cellmate and was released prior to Epstein's death, as mentioned by a correctional officer.

persons.name: Larry Nassar
persons.context: An envelope addressed to him (Item 4) was examined as part of the questioned documents case. The document does not elaborate on his connection to Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the Bureau of Prisons records; an inmate at MCC New York with registration number 76318-054. The documents detail his housing status, a self-harm incident, and disciplinary procedures.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cell mate (register number 78514-064) who was at the cell door when Epstein was found after an attempted hanging on July 23, 2019.

persons.name: Larry Nasser
persons.context: Name appears as the addressee on an envelope mentioned in the FBI lab report as part of a questioned documents examination.

persons.name: Jhonny Contreras
persons.context: Name appears on paper fragments referenced in ESDA lift analysis within the FBI lab notes.

persons.name: Donald
persons.context: Name appears on paper fragments referenced in ESDA lift analysis within the FBI lab notes.

persons.name: Special Agent FRI
persons.context: FBI Special Agent from the New York Field Office Violent Crimes Task Force corresponding about evidence shipment for case NY-3151227/Lab #2020-01577.

persons.name: Document Analyst- Forensic Examiner
persons.context: Forensic Examiner from the FBI Laboratory's Questioned Documents Unit who acknowledges receipt of evidence and outlines the examination process for the case.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: Defendant charged in a six-count indictment for conspiracy and making false documents. Admits to falsifying count and round slips at the MCC on August 9-10, 2019 and signs a deferred prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Jason E. Foy
persons.context: Partner at Foy & Seplowitz, LLC, who reported a threatening email against his client, Tova Noel, to the government.

persons.name: James Seplowitz
persons.context: Partner at Foy & Seplowitz, LLC, who initially received the threatening email targeting Tova Noel.

persons.name: Dan M.
persons.context: Repaired three hard disk drives from the DVR 2 system as part of the FBI's forensic examination.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: Defendant who admits to willfully completing false count and round slips at the MCC on August 9-10, 2019. Signs a deferred prosecution agreement to avoid prosecution if he complies with conditions.

persons.name: Montell Figgins
persons.context: Attorney representing Michael Thomas, signs the deferred prosecution agreement on his client's behalf.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: The United States Attorney whose office (USAO-SDNY) is prosecuting the case and signs the deferred prosecution agreements.

persons.name: Analisa Torres
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case who approves the exclusion of time under the Speedy Trial Act for the deferred prosecution agreement involving Michael Thomas.

persons.name: Corey L. Montgomery
persons.context: Appears as a sender/recipient in FBI email correspondence regarding uploading chain of custody documents to the case file.

persons.name: Victoria Tenpenny
persons.context: Her printed name appears on an FD-1004 evidence chain of custody form as the individual who collected or relinquished evidence.

connections.description: Reyes was Epstein's cellmate at the MCC prior to being released, as mentioned by a correctional officer during an interview.
Were housed together in cell 124 in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York as of July 23, 2019.
They are communicating via email regarding the submission, tracking, and processing of evidence for FBI case NY-3151227/Lab #2020-01577.
Foy is a partner at the law firm representing Tova Noel in connection with the Epstein death investigation.
Seplowitz is a partner at the law firm representing Tova Noel.
Montell Figgins is identified as the attorney representing defendant Michael Thomas in the deferred prosecution agreement.
An attorney named Jason (last name unclear from signature) represents defendant Tova Noel, as indicated by the signature on her deferred prosecution agreement.
Both were Bureau of Prisons employees charged in the same case (19 Cr. 830) for similar offenses of falsifying records at the MCC on the same dates, suggesting a coordinated action.
As U.S. Attorney, Audrey Strauss's office is prosecuting Michael Thomas and has offered him a deferred prosecution agreement.
As U.S. Attorney, Audrey Strauss's office is prosecuting Tova Noel and has offered her a deferred prosecution agreement.
Judge Torres approved the deferred prosecution agreement involving Tova Noel.
Judge Torres approved the deferred prosecution agreement involving Michael Thomas.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found hanging in his cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. A body alarm went off around 0638-0640 hours.

events.title: FBI Interview of Correctional Officer
events.description: The FBI interviewed a BOP correctional officer who responded to the incident, escorted EMS, followed the ambulance, and remained with Epstein's body until it was released to the medical examiner.

events.title: FBI Interview of Recreation Officer
events.description: The FBI interviewed a BOP recreation officer who stated his last interaction with Epstein was on August 9, 2019, informing Epstein he would need a new cellmate.

events.title: Letter Postmarked
events.description: A letter, later submitted for handwriting analysis, was postmarked. It was a 'return to sender' addressed to another BOP facility, with 'J. Epstein' written in the corner.

events.title: FBI Lab Declines Handwriting Analysis
events.description: A Forensic Document Examiner from the FBI Lab informed the case agent that handwriting analysis on the submitted letter could not be conducted due to major limitations in comparable style, wording, and verification of known writing from Epstein.

events.title: FBI Questioned Documents Examination
events.description: The FBI Laboratory conducts a forensic examination of documents, including items purported to be Jeffrey Epstein's writing and an envelope to Larry Nassar, to assess handwriting and indented writing.

events.title: Epstein Inmate Inquiry Record
events.description: A Bureau of Prisons inmate inquiry record for Jeffrey Epstein is included among the examined documents, showing his status at the New York Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Epstein's attempted hanging in SHU
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein attempted to hang himself in his cell (124) in the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York. His cell mate, Nicholas Tartaglione, was at the door. Staff intervened, removed an orange homemade rope from Epstein's neck; he was breathing but unresponsive.

events.title: Scheduled Discipline Hearing
events.description: A Discipline Hearing Officer (DHO) hearing was scheduled for Epstein regarding the charge of self-mutilation from July 23, 2019.

events.title: FBI Lab Submission 1
events.description: Evidence was submitted to the FBI Laboratory (Lab #2020-01577) for questioned document examination, including items purportedly containing the known writing of Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: FBI Lab Submission 2
events.description: Additional evidence, including an envelope addressed to 'Larry Nasser' and a greeting card, was submitted to the FBI Laboratory.

events.title: Evidence Submission Correspondence
events.description: Email exchange between an FBI Special Agent and a Document Analyst regarding the shipment and acknowledgment of evidence for case NY-3151227, assigned Lab number 2020-01577.

events.title: Website Screenshots Captured
events.description: Multiple screenshots were taken from the Artefacto furniture website, showing various product categories like lounge chairs, coffee tables, sofas, etc.

events.title: Letter to Nassar Postmarked
events.description: A letter addressed to Larry Nassar was postmarked. It was later returned to sender from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) with 'J. Epstein' written on it.

events.title: FBI Notified of Letter
events.description: A Bureau of Prisons Special Investigative Section (SIS) Lieutenant notified an FBI Special Agent about a 'return to sender' letter received by the MCC that had 'J. Epstein' written on it.

events.title: Laboratory Examination Request Submitted
events.description: The FBI New York Field Office formally submitted a request to the FBI Laboratory for handwriting analysis on the letter from Epstein's cell.

events.title: FBI Lab Report Issued
events.description: The FBI Laboratory's Questioned Documents Unit issued a report concluding that meaningful handwriting comparisons could not be conducted due to a lack of verified, comparable known writing samples from Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein at MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. A body alarm was activated around 6am, and personnel, including the interviewed BOP employee, attempted resuscitation.

events.title: FBI Interview of BOP Camera Technician
events.description: An unnamed Bureau of Prisons employee responsible for MCC cameras was interviewed by an AUSA, a Task Force Officer, and an FBI Special Agent. The technician detailed the extensive failures of the analog camera and DVR system around the time of Epstein's death.

events.title: Threatening Email Against Tova Noel
events.description: Attorneys Jason Foy and James Seplowitz received a threatening email targeting their client, former MCC guard Tova Noel, reading 'Go ahead and let your client Tova know, THIS ISN'T OVER!!' The FBI investigated the threat.

events.title: Submission of CART Video Evidence
events.description: The FBI's Computer Analysis and Response Team (CART) submitted two LTO-6 tapes containing a network archive of video images from MCC-NY video recorder hard drives as derivative evidence.

events.title: Forensic Examination of DVR System
events.description: The FBI's Digital Forensics Analysis Unit examined a DVR system, attempting to recover and export video recordings. DVR 1 was initially functional but failed in December 2019. DVR 2 had catastrophic failures and could not be restored.

events.title: Indictment of Thomas and Noel
events.description: A grand jury returned a six-count indictment against Michael Thomas and Tova Noel, charging them with conspiracy to defraud the United States and making false documents.

events.title: Deferred Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: The Southern District of New York entered into deferred prosecution agreements with Tova Noel and Michael Thomas, deferring prosecution for six months pending compliance with agreement terms.

events.title: Evidence Recharge Inquiry
events.description: The FBI Evidence Unit emailed to verify if evidence items (1B37, 1B38) were still with the OCME (Office of the Chief Medical Examiner) and needed to be recharged in the case system.

events.title: Confirmation of OCME Custody
events.description: The case agent confirmed that evidence items 1B37 and 1B38 were still in the custody of the non-FBI entity OCME.

events.title: False Count Slips at MCC
events.description: Michael Thomas and Tova Noel admit to willfully completing materially false count and round slips regarding required counts and rounds in the Special Housing Unit of the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: False Count Slips at MCC
events.description: Continuation of the falsification of count and round slips at the Metropolitan Correctional Center's Special Housing Unit.

events.title: Grand Jury Indictment
events.description: A grand jury returned a six-count indictment against Tova Noel, charging conspiracy and making false documents. The document references this indictment.

events.title: Court Approval Filed
events.description: The deferred prosecution agreements are filed with the court. Judge Analisa Torres approves the Speedy Trial Act exclusion for Michael Thomas's agreement.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was discovered unresponsive in his jail cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) with a fabricated noose around his neck, an apparent suicide.

events.title: Deferred Prosecution Agreement for Correctional Officers
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York entered into a deferred prosecution agreement with correctional officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas for False Records and Conspiracy.

events.title: Evidence Released to OIG
events.description: FBI Special Agents permanently transferred custody of numerous evidence items (e.g., hard drives, DVR footage) to the Office of the Inspector General (OIG).

events.title: Investigation Closed
events.description: The FBI requested closure of the Epstein death investigation, citing no criminality found, the OCME's suicide ruling, and the completion of the deferred prosecution agreement for the correctional officers.

events.title: OIG Returns Evidence to FBI
events.description: OIG Special Agent returned a large batch of evidence items (hard drives, etc.) to an FBI Special Agent.

keyFacts: A BOP correctional officer described the response to Epstein's death, including hearing a body alarm at ~0638-0640 hours, escorting EMS, and Epstein being pronounced dead at the hospital at ~0736 hours.
Another officer last spoke to Epstein on August 9, 2019, telling him he would need a new cellmate after Reyes was released.

The FBI Laboratory was requested to perform handwriting analysis on a letter postmarked August 13, 2019, addressed to another BOP facility, with 'J. Epstein' written on it, to determine if Epstein wrote it.
The FBI Laboratory's Questioned Documents Unit concluded it could not perform the handwriting analysis due to a lack of verified, comparable known writing samples from Jeffrey Epstein.
Evidence submitted for analysis included a greeting card addressed to 'Larry Nassar' and various documents from Epstein's cell purported to be his known writing, but none could be confirmed as such.

The FBI Lab attempted to verify known handwriting samples of Jeffrey Epstein from various submitted documents but found meaningful comparisons could not be conducted due to a lack of verified, comparable known writing.
Indented writing (IW) of unknown value was observed on three pages of the Epstein documents, with faint text including possible phrases like 'JEFF', 'CON', 'JEFF I WANt', and 'OVeR'.
An envelope addressed to convicted sex offender Larry Nassar was examined as part of the same case, suggesting a potential investigative link being explored.
The document includes a Bureau of Prisons record for Jeffrey Epstein dated July 30, 2019, showing he was an inmate at the New York MCC with register number 76318-054.
The torn edges of two pages from the Epstein documents (beginning 'AutHoR..' and 'JHONNY COlVTReRAS...') were noted to have been attached at one time.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein attempted to hang himself in his SHU cell at MCC New York using an orange homemade rope.
Epstein's cell mate at the time was Nicholas Tartaglione (register number 78514-064).
BOP records show Epstein was on 'complete bed rest' and had 'bathroom privileges only' as part of his housing status.
The FBI Laboratory was examining documents, including an envelope to 'Larry Nasser' and items with Epstein's purported known writing, for indented writing (IW) and handwriting comparisons.
The document includes a commissary price list and a visitor application form, indicating routine prison administrative processes during Epstein's incarceration.

The document contains numerous screenshots from the furniture website 'Artefacto.com' dated September 8, 2014, which may be relevant as potential evidence of financial transactions or property acquisitions.
An email from August 11, 2020, details FBI evidence handling for case NY-3151227, assigned Laboratory number 2020-01577, involving the Questioned Documents Unit.
The FBI Special Agent (FRI) from the New York Field Office is coordinating the shipment of evidence (including an item referred to as '1A with the letter') to the lab via FedEx.
The Document Analyst confirms receipt of evidence for specific serials (1839, 147) and notes a discrepancy, requesting the original envelope and greeting card if located.
The correspondence indicates an ongoing forensic document examination process related to this case.
The FBI attempted to determine if Jeffrey Epstein wrote a letter addressed to convicted sex offender Larry Nassar that was found as 'return to sender' from Epstein's cell.
The FBI Laboratory's Questioned Documents Unit concluded it could not perform a meaningful handwriting analysis due to a lack of verified, comparable known writing samples from Epstein.
The letter was postmarked August 13, 2019, and had 'J. Epstein Manhattan Correctional NYC NY 10007' written on it.
Known writing samples from Epstein's cell were submitted, but the FBI examiner noted they could not be confirmed as his writing, as many items in his cell were written by assistants.
The laboratory report notes indented writing of unknown value was found on some submitted documents, and ESDA (Electrostatic Detection Apparatus) lifts were made to preserve it.

The camera system at the MCC was severely outdated and malfunctioning at the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death. Only one hard drive was working on August 10, 2019, and a system failure had occurred on DVR 2 on July 29, 2019.
A Bureau of Prisons employee stated that replacing the failed hard drives would wipe all prior data, which was a concern when the Warden requested video after Epstein's death.
An FBI agent was reportedly the one who physically pulled out the DVR and hard drives from the MCC system after the incident.

Former MCC guard Tova Noel was the subject of a threatening email in May 2021, which was investigated by the FBI and linked to a subject in Las Vegas, NV, who was known for sending threatening messages based on news events.
Digital evidence from the MCC, including DVR system controllers and hard drives, was examined by the FBI's Digital Evidence Laboratory in Quantico, VA.
The FBI conducted an extensive forensic examination of a DVR system from August 2019 to May 2021, indicating the system was of investigative interest, likely from an Epstein-associated property.
The DVR system experienced significant hardware failures; DVR 1 failed in December 2019 and DVR 2 had catastrophic disk failures prior to FBI receipt, limiting video recovery.
Evidence items 1B37 and 1B38, described as 'Clothing released from New York Presbyterian Hospital,' were in the custody of the OCME (Office of the Chief Medical Examiner) as of early 2022.
Tova Noel and Michael Thomas entered into deferred prosecution agreements with the SDNY in May 2021, related to a November 2019 indictment for false document charges.
The document references a DVR vendor, 'SigNet Technologies,' and technical support was involved in the examination process.
Two Bureau of Prisons employees, Michael Thomas and Tova Noel, admitted to falsifying official count and round slips at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 9 and 10, 2019.

Both defendants entered into deferred prosecution agreements, avoiding immediate prosecution if they comply with conditions including cooperation with law enforcement and 100 hours of community service.
The agreements require the defendants to disclose all information related to their BOP employment and to be interviewed by the USAO-SDNY, FBI, and DOJ-OIG.
The case is directly related to the Bureau of Prisons and the Metropolitan Correctional Center, where Jeffrey Epstein was held prior to his death.
The U.S. Attorney's Office retained the right to proceed with prosecution if the defendants violate the agreement terms.
The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) ruled Jeffrey Epstein's cause of death as hanging and the manner of death as suicide.
Correctional officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas were charged with False Records and Conspiracy related to the Epstein case and entered a deferred prosecution agreement in May 2021.
Extensive digital evidence, including DVR footage from the MCC and numerous hard drives, was transferred from the FBI to the Office of the Inspector General (OIG) for their investigation.
The FBI closed its death investigation into Jeffrey Epstein in December 2022, finding no criminality beyond the charges against the correctional officers.
Evidence handling was a major focus, with detailed chain of custody forms, property receipts, and internal emails documenting transfers between FBI, OIG, and OCME.
